audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 45 minutes; modeling main idea vs detail.
teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check; one-sentence central idea summary.

learning_objectives: Identify a passage’s main claim in one sentence.
Distinguish central ideas from minor details.
Select paraphrases that capture the overall point.

structure.title: Central Ideas & Details
objectives: Eliminate choices that quote details only.
Prefer accurate paraphrases over exact wording.

lecture_script.script: Ask: What is the passage doing overall? Choose the option that captures that purpose, not a single fact.
We’ll discard a choice that quotes a detail but misses the passage’s point.
Underline the purpose verb-argues, explains, describes-then pick the matching paraphrase.

worked_example.passage: Community gardens, beyond supplying produce, build trust among neighbors who meet regularly to plan and share the harvest.
worked_example.question: Which choice states the central idea?

options.B: Community gardens foster social connections as well as food.

worked_example.explanation: The sentence stresses both produce and social trust-connections beyond food.

practice_set.passage: The biography notes that early failures taught techniques later evident in praised works.
practice_set.question: What is the central idea?

homework: Write a one-sentence central idea for three short passages.
Explain why a tempting detail choice is not the main idea for two items.
Create a paraphrase of a main idea without repeating phrases.
